title: Find out which court or tribunal to appeal to

body.content:
You might be able to appeal a court or tribunal decision if there's been a mistake interpreting the law, or a procedure hasn't been followed properly.  

You usually need permission to appeal from a judge.   

The rules are different in [Scotland](https://www.scotcourts.gov.uk/) and [Northern Ireland.](https://www.courtsni.gov.uk/)

^ The process is different if you want to [appeal a sentence or conviction from a criminal court](/appeal-against-sentence-conviction). ^

You might be able to appeal a court or tribunal decision if there’s been a mistake interpreting the law, or a procedure hasn’t been followed properly.

You usually need permission to appeal from a judge.

The rules are different in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

The process is different if you want to appeal a sentence or conviction from a criminal court.

nodes.title: Is your case on the multi-track?

body.content: Cases are usually put in the 'multi-track' if they involve amounts over £25,000 or if they're too complex to sort out in a day.

nodes.title: You need to send your appeal to the Court of Appeal (Civil Division)

body.content: Find out [how to appeal to the Court of Appeal.](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=991)
Find out how to appeal to the Court of Appeal.

nodes.title: You need to appeal to the Upper Tribunal

body.content:
The chamber of the Upper Tribunal you appeal to depends on what your case is about. 

##Benefits and health 

Appeal to the [Upper Tribunal (Administrative Appeals Chamber)](/administrative-appeals-tribunal) for cases including: 

* child support 
* benefits   
* special educational needs   
* mental health   
* war pensions   

There are [other cases](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=2745) this tribunal deals with. 

##Immigration and asylum

Go to the [Upper Tribunal (Immigration and Asylum Chamber)](/upper-tribunal-immigration-asylum) to appeal a decision made by the First-tier Tribunal (Immigration and Asylum Chamber).

##Land and property

Appeal to the [Upper Tribunal (Lands Chamber)](/appeal-upper-tribunal-lands) about land and property issues, including:

* leasehold disputes 
* compulsory purchase 
* tree preservation
* right to light 

It doesn't deal with land registration cases.

##Tax, land registration and charities

Appeal to the [Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery Chamber)](/tax-upper-tribunal) to challenge decisions made by organisations including: 

* Land Registry
* HMRC 
* Border Force 
* National Crime Agency

The chamber of the Upper Tribunal you appeal to depends on what your case is about.

Benefits and health

Appeal to the Upper Tribunal (Administrative Appeals Chamber) for cases including:

  • child support
  • benefits
  • special educational needs
  • mental health
  • war pensions

There are other cases this tribunal deals with.

Immigration and asylum

Go to the Upper Tribunal (Immigration and Asylum Chamber) to appeal a decision made by the First-tier Tribunal (Immigration and Asylum Chamber).

Land and property

Appeal to the Upper Tribunal (Lands Chamber) about land and property issues, including:

  • leasehold disputes
  • compulsory purchase
  • tree preservation
  • right to light

It doesn’t deal with land registration cases.

Tax, land registration and charities

Appeal to the Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery Chamber) to challenge decisions made by organisations including:

  • Land Registry
  • HMRC
  • Border Force
  • National Crime Agency

nodes.title: You need to appeal to the High Court

body.content:
You need to fill in an ['appellant's notice'](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=388) form to appeal. 

##If you live in London

Send it to:

$A
High Court Appeals Office
Royal Courts of Justice
Strand
London
WC2A 2LL
$A

##If you live outside of London

Send it to your local district registry. Ask the court that heard your case to tell you where your nearest district registry is.

You need to fill in an ‘appellant’s notice’ form to appeal.

If you live in London

Send it to:

High Court Appeals Office
Royal Courts of Justice
Strand
London
WC2A 2LL

If you live outside of London

Send it to your local district registry. Ask the court that heard your case to tell you where your nearest district registry is.

nodes.title: You usually need to appeal to a circuit judge

body.content:
You need to fill in an ['appellant's notice'](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=388) form to appeal. 

^ Contact the court where your hearing took place if you don’t think you should appeal to a circuit judge. ^

You need to fill in an ‘appellant’s notice’ form to appeal.

Contact the court where your hearing took place if you don’t think you should appeal to a circuit judge.

body.content: Find out [how to appeal to the Employment Appeal Tribunal](/appeal-employment-appeal-tribunal/overview).
Find out how to appeal to the Employment Appeal Tribunal.

nodes.title: You can't appeal your case any further
You need permission to appeal from the High Court judge

body.content:
Your appeal will then be heard at the Court of Appeal. 

Find out [how to appeal to the Court of Appeal.](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=991)

Your appeal will then be heard at the Court of Appeal.

Find out how to appeal to the Court of Appeal.

body.content: Find out [how to appeal to the Court of Appeal.](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=991)
Find out how to appeal to the Court of Appeal.

nodes.title: You need to send your appeal to the Court of Appeal (Civil Division)

body.content:
Find out [how to appeal to the Court of Appeal.](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=991)

If the original decision was made without a hearing (known as a 'paper hearing') you must apply for an 'oral hearing' at the High Court.

Find out how to appeal to the Court of Appeal.

If the original decision was made without a hearing (known as a ‘paper hearing’) you must apply for an ‘oral hearing’ at the High Court.
